\title{The correspondence between sonic points of ideal photon gas accretion and photon spheres}











\author{Yasutaka Koga}




\author{Tomohiro Harada}




\affiliation{Department of Physics, Rikkyo University, Toshima, Tokyo 171-8501, Japan}








\date{\today}

\begin{abstract}
In an accretion of fluid, its velocity may transit from subsonic to supersonic.
The point at which such transition occurs is called sonic point and often mathematically special.
We consider a steady-state and spherically symmetric accretion problem of ideal photon gas in general static spherically symmetric spacetime neglecting back reaction.
Our main result is that the EOS of ideal photon gas leads to correspondence between its sonic point and the photon sphere of the spacetime in general situations.
Despite of the dependence of the EOS on the dimension of spacetime,
this correspondence holds for spacetimes of arbitrary dimensions.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
{\label{{sec:introduction}}}
A photon sphere is a sphere on spacetime at which circular null geodesics exist.
In astrophysical cases, black holes usually have photon spheres near the horizon.
This structure is the characteristics of strong gravitational fields and helps us to identify black holes in the Universe by optical observations through its gravitational lensing.
\par
An accretion of fluid onto objects is a basic
problem in astrophysics and
the most important issue concerning growth of stars and black holes.
In an observationally view point, the accretion is considered to be responsible
for the X-ray emission due to the compression of the fluid.
This is also connected to observations of strong gravity fields in a general relativistic context.
\par
The first study of the accretion onto stars was established by Bondi\cite{bondi}.
He investigated stationary spherically symmetric flow of polytropic fluid in Newtonian gravity.
One of the interesting features is the existence of a critical point and transonic flow,
that is, flow which experiences transition between a subsonic and supersonic state.
Michel extended the problem to general relativity on Schwarzschild spacetime
under the assumption that the spacetime is not so strongly modified by the fluid and
also estimated several quantities on the critical point\cite{michel}.
For (anti-)de Sitter spacetime, Mach gave not only numerical calculations with a 
polytropic equation of state (EOS), but also the exact solutions of the accretion of fluid with isothermal EOSs\cite{mach}.
It was revealed that only for the radiation case, the explicit form of the radius of the critical point becomes surprisingly simple, $3M$.
This radius coincides to the photon sphere of the spacetime.
For general spacetime and EOSs, the existence of the unique solution of the accretion problem has been proved
by Chaverra\cite{chaverra}.
He analyzed the problem by methods of a dynamical system.
\par
In this paper, we see there exists the correspondence between sonic points of photon gas accretion and photon spheres in large class by generalizing the analysis\cite{chaverra} to arbitrary dimensions.
We consider general static spherically symmetric spacetime

\section{The proof of Theorem \ref{theorem:main}: The correspondence among the points}
{\label{{sec:proof}}}
In this section, we see the correspondence among the three objects; the photon sphere, the critical point and the sonic point of our ideal photon gas accretion problem and complete the proof of the main theorem.
\par
From Lemma \ref{lemma:photonsphere} and \ref{lemma:photongascritical}, we can establish
the following corollary about the correspondence between photon spheres and critical points of ideal photon gas accretion.
\begin{corollary}
{\label{{corollary:spherecritical}}}
If the spacetime has photon spheres, there exists a critical point of the same radius for each of the spheres.
Furthermore, for an unstable photon sphere, the critical point on the same radius is always a saddle point while for a stable one, the corresponding critical point is an extremum point.
\end{corollary}
The critical point radius $r_c$ depends on $\mu$ in general.
However, the photon gas accretion is interesting in the sense that its critical radius does not depend on $\mu$ and this fact is responsible for the correspondence.
\par
Ideal photon gas satisfies the condition of EOS in Lemma \ref{lemma:sonic-critical}
since $v_s^2(n)=\gamma-1$ and the lemma can be applied.
Then we have the corollary about the relation between critical points and sonic points.
\begin{corollary}
{\label{{corollary:criticalsonic}}}
For any physical transonic accretion flow of the ideal photon gas accretion, its sonic point is a critical and saddle point.
\end{corollary}
Then, the above two corollaries complete the proof of Theorem.


\section{Conclusion}
{\label{{sec:conclusion}}}
In this work, at first we derived the conditions for photon spheres, the radius and the stability of the corresponding circular orbit of null geodesics.
Next, we generalize the accretion analysis given by E. Chaverra and O. Sarbach\cite{chaverra}
to arbitrary dimensions and discussed about the relation between sonic points and critical points in general.
Then, for a fluid made of ideal photon gas, it was shown that radius of a sonic point always coincides with (one of) photon spheres for physical solutions of the accretion problem.
\par
We can say that a photon sphere is indeed special even for the radial accretion
because the flow can be interpreted as a set of geodesic motions of photons
and some of the photons must go round on the sphere.
However, the sound speed and the fluid velocity are macroscopic quantities.
The reason for the correspondence is not yet so
clear. 
Since the correspondence seems to be originate from the
microscopic construction of radiation fluid, we conjecture that the
correspondence will be seen in more general situations, such as 
axially symmetric steady-state accretion flows onto stationarily 
rotating black holes.
\par
The correspondence can be broken if the effects of the back reaction is included.
However, since photon spheres are usually located near the source of
gravity, it would be verified to neglect the self-gravity of the fluid
and the correspondence still holds even in that case. 
\par
 It should be noted that the present discussion applies not only to accretion but also to outflow or stellar wind as long as it is steady-state and spherically symmetric.
